articles.headline: Tighter Credit Only Adds to Auto Industry’s Troubles
articles.snippet: With banks tightening up their lending, any hope for a recovery in vehicle sales this year has been dashed.
articles.abstract: With banks tightening up their lending, any hope for a recovery in vehicle sales this year has been dashed.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — After enduring a brutal sales slump caused by high gas prices and a faltering economy, the last thing the American auto industry needed was a credit crisis.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: The U.S. Financial Crisis Is Spreading to Europe
articles.snippet: Europe now faces a financial crisis almost as grave as that in the United States — demonstrating how swiftly this contagion is spreading around the world.
articles.abstract: Europe now faces a financial crisis almost as grave as that in the United States — demonstrating how swiftly this contagion is spreading around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Barely a week after Europeans rebuffed American pleas to join in their bailout of the banking system, Europe now faces a financial crisis almost as grave as that in the United States  demonstrating how swiftly this contagion is spreading around the world.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Move May Relax Asset Rule
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. issued an interpretation of an accounting standard that could make it easier for banks to report smaller losses when they announce results for the third quarter.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. issued an interpretation of an accounting standard that could make it easier for banks to report smaller losses when they announce results for the third quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under pressure from banks and legislators, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued an interpretation of an accounting standard that could make it easier for banks to report smaller losses, or perhaps even profits, when they announce results for the third quarter, which ended Tuesday.

articles.headline: A Squeeze on Leading Fund Chiefs
articles.snippet: While their showing was better than that of the broad stock market, some of the most successful hedge fund managers lost big lately as the markets turned chaotic.
articles.abstract: While their showing was better than that of the broad stock market, some of the most successful hedge fund managers lost big lately as the markets turned chaotic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lee S. Ainslie, Louis M. Bacon and Daniel Loeb are some of the most successful hedge fund managers around. But even they lost big lately as the markets turned chaotic.

articles.headline: Under Strain, Cities Are Cutting Back Projects
articles.snippet: Local governments have been effectively shut out of the bond markets, raising the cost of operations and threatening larger projects.
articles.abstract: Local governments have been effectively shut out of the bond markets, raising the cost of operations and threatening larger projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cities, states and other local governments have been effectively shut out of the bond markets for the last two weeks, raising the cost of day-to-day operations, threatening longer-term projects and dampening a broad source of jobs and stability at a time when other parts of the economy are weakening.

articles.headline: Lesson From a Crisis: When Trust Vanishes, Worry
articles.snippet: The basic mechanics of how the economy might fall into a severe recession look quite similar to those that caused the Depression.
articles.abstract: The basic mechanics of how the economy might fall into a severe recession look quite similar to those that caused the Depression.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1929, Meyer Mishkin owned a shop in New York that sold silk shirts to workingmen. When the stock market crashed that October, he turned to his son, then a student at City College, and offered a version of this sentiment: It serves those rich scoundrels right.

articles.headline: Pressure Builds on House After Senate Backs Bailout
articles.snippet: The Senate strongly endorsed the plan, leaving backers hopeful that the easy approval, along with popular enticements, would lead to quick House passage.
articles.abstract: The Senate strongly endorsed the plan, leaving backers hopeful that the easy approval, along with popular enticements, would lead to quick House passage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Senate strongly endorsed the $700 billion economic bailout plan on Wednesday, leaving backers optimistic that the easy approval, coupled with an array of popular additions, would lead to House acceptance by Friday and end the legislative uncertainty that has rocked the markets.
